title: You Were The First
post_title: Half a year ago, it had not been part of the plan that he should run into an old friend from college – if he wanted to call Dean Winchester a friend, when in reality they had been – but that was not the point.
comment:
Half a year ago, it had not been part of the plan that he should run into an old friend from college – if he wanted to call Dean Winchester a friend, when in reality they had been – but that was not the point.
No, here he was lying low in Lawrence, Kansas, his Mustang needed some loving care, and he just happened to enter a shop and see Dean Winchester.
“Crowley!”
And the rest, as they said, had been history.
He had now spent the last six months in this good-for-nothing town and any investigation he had had to be worried about had long since blown over. He could leave, and he would.
He just wanted to spend one last evening with Dean, as they had done so often lately.
They had been talking about nothing important – Dean had ben complaining about a blind date his brother had sent him on – when his – friend? – suddenly turned to him and asked, “What about you, anyway? No one special on the horizon?”
And he could have told him that he usually got what he wanted, only he couldn’t, because Dean Winchester had been the one thing he had ever had to leave behind.
“You were the first“. The words tumbled out of his mouth before he could stop himself.
Dean stared at him. “What are you –“
“And the last” he admitted, feeling as defeated as he sounded, because eh had seen what his life would have been like if he had chosen a different path, if he had decided to act back then, he might have been –
Might have been – but that was deluding himself, as he very well knew. He was never meant for a straight path in life, and it was good that eh had acted accordingly. He would only have dragged Dean Winchester down in the mud with him, and what then? He would have come to hate him, eventually anyway. His lovers usually did. But in this case, he didn’t think he would have been able to bear it.
Dean looked at him, then shook his head slowly, as if contemplating something.
Then, “You really took your time, peaches.”
“What?” he asked, his confusion only getting stronger when Dean kissed him.
“You were no exactly – no that’s not true” Dean eventually explained. “But I could always tell it was you. Kept an eye on the news, you see, just out of… But doesn’t matter.”
He laughed because there was nothing else to do.
Dean chuckled himself. “I know. Well, now that that’s out in the open, how do we proceed?”
“What –“
“What do we do about this? Because I’m not about to leave my life behind. I’ve got my shop, and my niece and nephew, and Sammy – Sammy would never let me get away, and man, I can’t imagine what bobby would do, so you have to –“
“What makes you think I would even want –“
And then Dean kissed him. Kissed him like it was nothing, like the years had not passed and eh found himself responding and remembering why he had always been the most exhilarating man he had ever met.
When they broke off, Dean asked, “So?”
It should not have been easy – or no – it should have been easy. He should have known exactly what he wanted, ands that it was to leave and continue on his path. Some things were not meant to be, and so he couldn’t just –
“We’ll have to come up with a plan.”
Dean kissed him again.
A year later
“No, no, of course we understand, Agent – you’re not the first, just an unfortunate coincidence –“ And Dean led the woman out of their house with the practice of someone who did so on a regular basis.
“That should be enough visits from the feds for the rest of the year, don’t you think?” he asked, coming into the living room. “At least until they work their way through the pile yet again.”
“You never know” he replied.
Dean shook his head. “Would have been easier if we’d manage to make it look like you were dead –“
“Oh” he brightened up ”I am sure – ”
One look from his husband made it clear that plan was not going to go anywhere. Apparently they would be stuck handling the agents for quite some time to come.
Not that he could bring himself to mind too much. Business was booming, even Sam had calmed down somewhat when it came to their, as most people believed it, whirlwind romance, and most importantly, he had Dean.
“I don’t know about you, but I could rely use a glass of Craig” he declared.
There really was nothing to do but to oblige, but he couldn’t bring himself to mind all too much about it.
writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.

title: Well, That Worked Out Great
post_title: Normally, he enjoyed his meetings with his lawyer.
comment:
Normally, he enjoyed his meetings with his lawyer.
Mostly because Dean Winchester was not only clever and competent, but also one of the most beautiful men he had ever met, and they had been flirting rather heavily as of late. Plus, he really had been careful when it came to one-night stands in the past few months, so it was time to scratch that particular itch.
Sadly, it was not to be, because a surprise waited for him today.
“We need to talk” Dean announced as quickly as he could – he had barely had time to sit down. “This can’t go on. If you receive another shipment from Chicago – the kind I don’t know anything about and I wouldn’t even admit to under torture – “
“What?”
Don’t play coy with me Peaches, I am talking about you having to shut down part of your operation at least for the time being.”
“I don’t see –“
“Someone blabbed, that’s it, and now people are on alert.”
“I have always made sure that my employees know that they should be very careful when speaking to others about their jobs.”
“Well, that worked out great” Deans aid sarcastically, and Crowley resisted the urge to roll his eyes because no one was going to turn him into a petulant five-year-old, not even one of the most enchanting men he had ever met. “So now you’ve got a private detective after you, and if he uncovers anything –“
“There is nothing to uncover” he interrupted him smoothly because well, there ought not to be and he would make sure that –
And then Dean looked at him and he became very aware that this man did indeed know everything. He had no idea how. Yes, he was a lawyer, but Crowley had always made sure that those he
worked
with either only knew of his legal or his illegal activities, and that there never was a cross between them, only that Dean Winchester –
But how? It made no sense at all, it was utterly ridiculous –
And then he shook his head. “You might be careful, but some in your organization are not as loyal as you think. Or no – I know you – you enjoy the risk, don’t you?”
He was still trying to find an answer when he exploded, “Damn you, Crwoley! You’re smarter than this! One of the reasons I like you so much as a client. I always thought you would never do something to risk your business, both of them, and yet you insist on having people like Simmons on your pay roll who hate your guts –“
“Everyone hates my guts” he pointed out correctly because he was not about to start lying again now when they were finally honest with open another – and he himself was, now that he thought about it, honest with anyone for the very first time in – years? Decades? His life?
“That doesn’t mean you should play with fire. But of course that’s it – you grew bored and you wanted to spice things up a bit.”
Now he was growing uncomfortable, not euclase Dean Winchester continued to berate him, but because he had hit the nail on the head. While he would never have called being on top of things truly boring, things could grow stale after a while, and just a little –
“Alright we need to clean this up.”
“We do?” he asked before he could stop himself.
Dean glared at him-
“What I want to say” he quickly explained “is that I am very capable of –“
“I know you are but I want to avoid a death toll in the dozens, you know it would only catch someone’s attention, and then we’d be right back at the beginning. Much easier to frame them for something, especially because they have to be guilty of certain things working for you. The trick is not to let on anything about – well, you know. But let’s see.”
And Dean Winchester, who he until now had considered one of the most law-abiding persons he had ever met (although he would alter admit that he would have thought him still as attractive as he did if that had indeed been the case) settled down to a lengthy discussion about his… more illegal activities and what they would have to do to make sure Crowley was safe.
He would say this.
He had most definitely not expected that.
A year later
“Ransom called from Tulsa, don’t worry, I handled it.”
“Thank you, I was busy with the new contracts anyway –“
His husband grinned at him. “I’ll look them over later just to make sure.”
He wasn’t quite certain how Dean had taken over the legal side of – well all sides of his business, but he was not going to complain.
“Anyway. What’s for dinner?”
writing_prompt: When Crowley hired Dean Winchester as his lawyer, he never expected the man to uncover his illegal empire, let alone help him run it more efficiently—and with far fewer bodies to clean up.

title: I Won't Let You Down
post_title: Neal liked to think that even when he had still been looked for by the FBI, he had had standards. There were some things he simply  would not do, and endangering people had always been one of them. Peter knew that, and it was probably one of the reasons he had chased him down, yes, but also been friendly and professional once he’d got him, and why they were close friends now.
comment:
Neal liked to think that even when he had still been looked for by the FBI, he had had standards. There were some things he simply  would not do, and endangering people had always been one of them. Peter knew that, and it was probably one of the reasons he had chased him down, yes, but also been friendly and professional once he’d got him, and why they were close friends now.
Still, of course he was wary when it came to Neal. He had not always been on his best behaviour, and he had perhaps realized what he truly wanted, where he belonged, a little too late, but that didn’t mean – at least he hoped it didn’t – that he couldn’t work himself back in his good graces.
And then Agent Lane happened, was sent over to White Collar to make sure everything was above board because of course there was talk that Peter didn’t know how to keep a separation between work and his private life and he and Neal were too close – thankfully not in
that
way because no one could fathom Peter cheating on Elizabeth, not even the biggest of gossips – but in the whole “we are family” way which made Neal feel a little bit guilty because – well – again, he had not been as much of an asset as he should have Eben considering the conditions under which he’d been released inti Peter’s custody. Still, no one seemed to really care, and then Agent Lane waltzed in with his talks of regulations and how CIs should be treated and that Peter had not filled out the necessary forms, which was deictic because this was Peter Burke they were talking about and
of course
he had submitted all the paperwork he needed to, only that when someone wanted to make someone’s life a living hell they usually found ways to succeed.
It was not difficult to tell that Peter had been rather stressed lately.
And now here they were, and a forged van Eyck has just shown up, and Neal could just tell that Lane was trying to trace it back to him, only that – well –
It was rather awkward, considering everything, but he was innocent. He had no idea where this forgery even came from, but nonetheless this man was determined to see it traced back to him and therefore to Peter, and his friend was not even talking to him about this, which seemed to indicate that he at least suspected him –
Neal knew it shouldn’t have hurt. It did regardless.
But even so, even if there was not… all of this to deal with, he would still have been worried because it just wasn’t normal for them not to speak for a few days not anymore, and he was just as worried as if it had been Mozzie or El or June or Diana or Clinton…
He really had developed quite the social circle, he suddenly realized. There had been a time when he had avoided that, if only to make it easier to leave.
But that was neither here nor there – right now, he had other things to deal with.
And so he went to see Peter in his office.
He was working away on some files but immediately raised his head. “Ah Neal. Anything wrong?”
There was no suspicion in his gaze, so he probably didn’t
really
think he had the painting stashed away somewhere which was an improvement to the beginning of their work relationship, all in all, and Neal sat down and shrugged. “Not really. Just don’t really get along with the new guy, that’s all.”
Peter grimaced. “His assessment will only take two more days, or so he tells me. No idea what he hopes to find.”
He was about to say something when he sighed and said, “The truth is – Neal, you should keep your head down. If guys like this want to find anything, they usually do, and I don’t want to –“
“So what if we give him something to chase?” he suggested because he already had a few ideas. After all, they had to figure out a way to do their work, while they could not do efficiently with the guy hanging around, and something like calling in anonymous tips about stolen art was hardly against the law…
“Neal…”
"I won't let you down" he promised, knowing even as he did so that Peter had no reason to believe him. With everything he had done in the past few years, with how much trouble he’d brought him, there was absolutely no reason to –
And Peter said “Fine” and nodded at him and Neal was once more left to marvel at this man who for some reason decided to make him his project.
Time to call Mozzie.
writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.

title: How Did This Happen?
post_title: She was a beautiful lady, alright. There was a reason she was the flagship of the Federation, destined to go where no man had gone before; and she would go far, he knew that – well, even farer than she had before. Granted, he didn’t know much about this Captain Kirk as of yet, just that he had seemed to be a boy wonder at the Academy, and those might work out for the best or end up useless; but as long as he had something to tinker with and an engine to take care of, he would be alright.
comment:
She was a beautiful lady, alright. There was a reason she was the flagship of the Federation, destined to go where no man had gone before; and she would go far, he knew that – well, even farer than she had before. Granted, he didn’t know much about this Captain Kirk as of yet, just that he had seemed to be a boy wonder at the academy, and those might work out for the best or end up useless; but as long as he had something to tinker with and an engine to take care of, he would be alright.
After all, he had been through many a storm already with different ships, how difficult could it be?
A few emergencies later, he had to admit he had not reroll considered what it would mean to have to make things up on the fly when everything went wrong, but still, he managed. After all, that was what he was here for. He was not just tinkering away on old cars in Edinburgh, as his grandfather had done; he was working on a spaceship.
Still, it was not a welcome surprise when they suddenly found themselves dead in the water – dead in space, he supposed he should call it.
The life support still worked, but other than that, nothing. Which in some way was good news because at least he had time to figure out what was going on without them suffocating in the meantime.
Still, he knew what he had to do in such a moment as this, so he made his way unto the bridge.
”Scotty, how did this happen?” were the first words out of the captain’s mouth and despite everything, he had to suppress a smiled. The instructors in the academy had always told him he should stay professional because no captain worth a damn would call him by a nickname, but Captain Kirk had proven them wrong right from the start.
“I don’t know sir, but I am working on it.”
He nodded. “Spock?”
Mr. Spock, as could be expected for any good scienced officer, had a few theories, but nothing concrete as yet, whereas the good doctor was slightly worried about the crew, as he always was, but rather happy that sickbay was still fully operational, so to speak.
Kirk nodded at him and he returned to the engine room to figure out what was going on.
It didn’t take long to learn that actually, everything should have been working perfectly. There really was no reason for it not to, apart from the fact that they were in space and everything was possible, there. He quickly did the math. Wall in all, things were not too bad – they still had a little over 84-hours until they would all end up dead; they’d had to dela with much less.
What he hadn’t counted on was how it would feel too slowly watch all their theories crumble to dust while absolutely nothing changed. It was just as well thy were blessed with such a Captain as Jim kirk and such a first officer as Mr. Spock, because these two at least kept a cool head. And Doctor McCoy for all that he could start complaining as soon as he woke up in the morning, also knew what to do in such moments as this.
Still, they had to find something, and soon.
It was young Chekov who gave him the idea. “You know, sir, in Russia, we used to do something called
schemitsa
. Bear hunting. It was… a trap. When a bear tried to get through, it would get stuck and either starve or be killed when the hunters returned.”
He nodded more out of politeness but then realized that this might actually make sense. Trapping her in this place, waiting for whoever had laid the trap to come back…
“Sir” he hit the intercom, ”I’ll need more scans of the area immediately surrounding the Enterprise. I think there might be something there.”
“Consider it done, Mr. Scott” the Captains’ voice replied.
A few minutes later, he had the scans. Yes – just a small but significant higher concentration of epsilon rays than should have been there. It might not have been much, but it was what he could get, and he would work with it.
“Sir!” he all but shouted through the intercom again. “I Think I’ve got it!”
It was a little bit more complicated than just dismantling the set of rays that had been laid out like a bear trap in Chekov’s story, but still, three hours later they were free, and he was rather sure it would make an interesting report for the captain to send in.
When he entered the Bridge, the captain said, “Well done, Mr. Scott.”
“Aye, thank you, Captain. All in a day’s work.”
writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.

title: This Is Getting Ridiculous
post_title: “This is getting ridiculous, wouldn’t you say, Father?” Lady Felicia asks one day as they are having tea in the rectory garden.
comment:
“This is getting ridiculous, wouldn’t you say, Father?” Lady Felicia asks one day as they are having tea in the rectory garden.
While he is aware that she is prone to overexaggeration, much as dear Mrs. M is prone to taking the Bible too seriously, and has long since grown accustomed to their respective… well… spleens, he simply raises an eyebrow and asks, “What exactly is ridiculous, Lady F?”
“Oh, don’t act like that. Sid and the dear inspector. You have to admit it’s obvious, only they won’t admit it to themselves.”
He has to say that, as of late, it truly is rather mysterious as to why these two have not been able to figure things out. Sid has not done any breaking and entering in months, unless it be for a case, and Inspector Sullivan has grown more and more lenient in certain ways, to the point where he will only put up a token it of resistance when Father Brown himself shows up at a crime scene. Honestly, it’s sort of a nice change of pace, even if he says so himself.
Still – there are some things they have to consider because, despite God declaring that love comes from him and as such is a gift to be treasured, there are people who do not agree, who think that some forms of love should not be allowed, that it is sinful when it truly is not, when it really could not be, not like this, when both of them clearly feel the same.
It’s rather sad, and he wishes the world were different, despite living in the best possible world, naturally, but still…
“It does appear that the inspector is no longer nearly as annoyed with Sid as he used to be” he therefore declares diplomatically, because it’s the closest he can come to actually admitting any of this out loud out of sheer habit, and she gives him a knowing smile.
“I think it’s time to... encourage them wouldn’t you say?”
”I don’t think the Inspector would like that very much” is his honest answer.
“Oh he’ll thank me later” she says and he knows from experience that eh can’t dissuade her, but at least he has a good enough opinion of the inspector’s heart not to worry too much.
As it turns out in the coming weeks, Lady felicia’s plan is to throw them together as much as possible and hope for the best. Which might of course work, but at the same time, eh has the feeling that the inspector might need a bit more encouragement than that. Sid – oh, he’s under no delusions in that regard. Sid is probably more than ready to throw caution to the wind, but then, he’s not working for the police and has seen the inside of a jail more than once, even though until now he’s gotten off lightly.
And so, he watches the two of them clear out lady F’s shed because apparently the Gardner doesn’t have time, which is a lie, or work away on her car, because for some reason the chauffeur seems to have gone the way of the gardener (at elates that’s an activity they both enjoy) and then, on a rather memorable occasion, keep the two small girls of her visiting cousin occupied (as it turns out to no one’s surprise, the good inspector is better at keeping everyone in check while Sid takes care of the entertainment).
As far as he can tell, at least they seem to be getting along now, and to no longer pretend that they don’t like each other, although they clearly have not gone any further…
Again, it is not his life, and he really should not know about this, thinking of the church, so he decides to let things take their course, and it seems that they do, about two weeks later, if he is right.
He certainly has never seen Inspector Sullivan smile at a crime scene, but the real surprise is that he simply looks at him and shrugs. “Coming to take a guess, Father?”
“I just want to pray for the poor soul, and see if I can identify them.”
“In that case… be my guest.”
He decides not to comment because certainly the inspector has his reasons.
Said reasons how up ten minutes on their favorite motorbike and Father brown, even if he does say so himself, does a very good impression of a man who is much too busy realizing why the inspector is hurrying over the street.
Even so, he catches Sergeant Goodfellow’s eyes and they smiled at one another.
At least he will be able to tell Lady Felicia that all is well the next time she comes over for tea. If she has not yet noticed herself, that is.
writing_prompt: A small English village is abuzz with gossip as Lady Felicia takes it upon herself to "encourage" a reluctant inspector and a charming rogue to admit their feelings for each other, much to the quiet amusement of Father Brown.

title: Did You Stick To The Plan?
fandoms: Good Omens - Neil Gaiman & Terry Pratchett
post_title: So far, things had been going as well as they could be expected to. He was trying to influence young warlock towards Hell, while Aziraphale was doing the same but into the other direction, and as far as Crowley could tell from his experience which was rather… a lot more than he would admit to because he had always had a soft spot for kids, no matter whether they were literal hell spawn or not, Warlock was as ordinary as he could be.
comment:
So far, things had been going as well as they could be expected to. He was trying to influence young warlock towards Hell, while Aziraphale was doing the same but into the other direction, and as far as Crowley could tell from his experience which was rather… a lot more than he would admit to because he had always had a soft spot for kids, no matter whether they were literal hell spawn or not, Warlock was as ordinary as he could be.
And then Aziraphale came to him, looking worried and haggard, and he knew something was up.
What had happened? He certainly had not been interested in nuclear weapons during the lesson last week, and he had looked rather bored when Crowley had told him that bedtime story about Godzilla last night –
“It’s just – oh dear – you better come.”
Normally they tried to make it seem like they didn’t know one another so he immediately felt worried as they repaired to Warlock’s room.
As first, he didn’t think too much of it – he was playing with one of his Lego sets…
And then he heard what he was
actually
saying.
“Aaaaaaaaah, it burns, save yourselves!
Noooooooooooooo Father!
It’s got me it’s too late tell your mother I love her…l”
All in all it was a rather impressive display, he would say that, especially since the child in question was only six years old, but that didn’t distract him from the fact that the theme of his play was rather dark and that this was not something a child should come up with… on the other hand, maybe it was. Yes, he knew children, but that also meant he was aware they could come up with all kinds of stuff.
But that Aziraphale had called him in meant that there might be more to this story.. as a matter of fact, when he turned to him, he looked… guilty?
But why should he feel guilty, if there was one thing he knew, it was that they had an arrangement when it came to Warlock – one of many over the centuries, although they all paled in front if the big one that had been in place almost since they had known each other –
There was only one explanation, he realized, and that was that the angel had mentioned something he shouldn’t have.
“Did you stick to the plan?” he asked even though it was a very stupid inquiry. Not because of his thought process, as just demonstrated, but because it was the wrong wording (and eh should know If there was one thing he could count on when it came to Aziraphale, it would that he would remain on the path he was absolutely sure God had chosen for him –
Only that he looked – well – not very comfortable right now and yes – here came the hand-wringing –
Something was up. “Angel” he hissed. “What’s going on?”
“Well he wanted to hear about the destruction of Pompei”.
“What – the – he’s five! How did he even know about that?”
“As far as I can understand, he was playing by himself in a corridor” that often happened with children of rich parents, Crowley knew, all the money in the world and yet they ended up with little to no friends, he would have to talk to Mrs. Downing about kindergarten again, they could not just let this happen “and his father had a meeting bin his office and the door was open and someone compared the current geopolitical situation with 79 AC.”
Which was idiotic because, well, most of what was wrong with things currently was the humans fault. Crowley knew that, his angel knew that, and they knew it too. But of course that was not what Warlock would take from the story, as he was clearly demonstrating because he was currently watching family melt in his mind with relish.
This did not seem very heavenly to Crowley. Didn’t even seem very hell-y either, if he was being honest. They would have let them suffer more.
Not that he was about to suggest that. They had enough trouble as it was.
“Fine. So what do we do now?”
“I’ve been thinking about taking him there –“
“We can’t just tell his parents were taking a small child on a holiday, and he’d probably have fun. That would be counterproductive.”
“What do you suggest then –“
“Let me try.”
And, with his experience when it came to children, ten minutes later he had Warlock stage a rescue operation that would never have worked in real life, but who was he to judge? As far as he was concerned this was progress.
And if Aziraphale stayed and watched them both with something like awe on his face, neither of them would mention it for the next few decades to come.
writing_prompt: Aziraphale and Crowley are tasked with subtly influencing a young child, but when the boy starts reenacting disturbingly dark historical events with his toys, the two must figure out how to steer him back on track—without breaking their delicate arrangement or alarming his parents.

title: Did You Hear That?
post_title: It was nothing new that Richard had… problems when it came to acclimatizing himself to Saint Marie, much as Camille and her mother and the rest of the team had been trying their best.
comment:
It was nothing new that Richard had… problems when it came to acclimatizing himself to Saint Marie, much as Camille and her mother and the rest of the team had been trying their best. He did accept their invitations now and then, these days, it was true, but he was still wearing the same suits he had when transferring here, was obviously not trying to find a home (which really, he should because the shack was no place to live. What if he ever wanted to… get something better for… certain reasons? He could hardly stay on the beach then…), and when it came to the island’s style of living…
Better not touch that particular subject, but still.
True, though, all of this did not explain everything, and Camille would blame herself for it for quite longer than she’d let anyone know.
But the point was, she had driven to the shack yet again on an evening where there was not much to do. Usually, she found Richard reading, but today, he was on his knees on the floor, seemingly searching for something, and she cleared her throat.
He looked up and she was taken aback by the somewhat frantic look in his eyes.
“Richard? Is everything alright?” she asked even though it was clear it very much wasn’t.
“I – I – there was a bug, it was the size of a small puppy, and I blinked and it was gone, and –“
She would have assumed he was hallucinating if she didn’t know there were indeed a few large insects on Saint Marie.
There was a very quiet noise in a corner, the sort of thing she did not pay attention to because she had grown up here. Richard, of course, was a different matter.
“Did you hear that?” he asked his eyes wide, reeling around, and Camille knew she had to act.
“Alright that’s it. Veranda”. And she gently contemplated him outside and into a chair out there. “Take a few dep breaths.” He did as she hurried inside and got a cold bottle of mineral water from the fridge (that really was making some unnatural noises – she would have to ask about that eventually, but later, once everything was…)
“Here” she said, passing him the bottle, and was relieved to find he wasn’t too out of it to realize that she wanted him to take a deep drag and breathe.
They were silent for a minute or two and then Richard said quietly “Thank you”.
She wanted, but there was nothing. Then, she inquired, “Are you alright?” Tone, she had learned early on, was everything with Richard; and she was very careful lest she sound accusatory or even as if she was ridiculing him.
“I – yes, I am now, thank you.”
“Richard…”
He took a deep breath. “I have to apologize.”
“You don’t have to apologize.”
“It’s just sometimes I get these – these thoughts and – there was this really big critter, you see and – “ he took another deep shaky breath. “It just – goes round and round in my head and I can’t stop it. It’s not – It’s not normal of course, I mean –“
No, it most likely wasn’t… from all that she knew of him, she would guess obsessive-compulsive (not that she liked him any less for it, and she was ready to bet the others felt the same). “And? Do you feel better now?”
He nodded miserably and she reached out to lay a hand on his arm. “Richard, you have to know that – yes, I am aware this can’t be easy for you. But there are ways to manage.”
“And how? I can’t get off this bloody island – “
Now, that was not something she liked to hear but she moved on from it, for now. “I meant – well – you could be looking for a place with proper doors and windows –“
“Have you seen the prices around here? And it
has
to be close to the station, and it
doesn’t
have to be too big, alright, maybe that wouldn’t be a problem, but – “
She stayed quiet so he wouldn’t realize what he had just divulged, instead saying, “I will gladly help you.”
That shut him up.
And so, she was the one to grab a notepad for once and start making a list.
He did protest when it came to some things – seafood and different clothes – but she told him that some things had to give, and eventually,
eventually
, she won that fight.
Really, it was only the beginning of some happy developments.
Even if it meant that she had to deal with these – Richard insisted on calling them “episodes” when really it was nothing.
And in that, he too, mellowed over the years, the fact that she eventually found him pouring over an encyclopedia of insects with their five-year-old proving it.
writing_prompt: A detective struggling to adjust to life on a tropical island finds himself in a standoff with a bug the size of a small puppy, leading his partner to step in and help him confront more than just the local wildlife.

title: That was good work
post_title: Morse, Robbie had heard that long before he met the man himself, was… difficult.
comment:
Morse, Robbie had heard that long before he met the man himself, was… difficult. Which was not the word his colleagues had used precisely, but still, it came close enough, and he felt that one should have respect for a superior officer, especially one who had his success rate, Even if he never seemed to have found a sergeant who worked well with him. But that, too, didn’t have to mean anything – some people just preferred working alone, and Morse certainly brought the results that they needed, so that no one had ever complained, apart from, if he remembered correctly, Superintendent Strange, but there were a few
strange
rumours going on about him and the lodge, too, so he thought their boss probably didn’t have a leg to stand on when it came to this.
Still  morse had a reputation, so when he had happened across him on a case, he hadn’t expected much. He’d probably have the whole thing solved in a day or two, and Robbie would be left to do the paperwork, which was usually the case anyway. He supposed it was something to have met the big man, anyway.
Apart from –
Well, it was something else to actually
see
him work. If it had not been for DCI Morse’s well-known… opinions eh would call them he would have assumed that the man should have been even above Superintendent Strange in rank at this point, but instead, here he was, solving one of the most complicated murders Robbie had ever seen like it was nothing.
Afterwards, they went their separate ways, naturally.
Until the next case where Morse needed a sergeant and Robbie was available. He thought so at the time, at least – later much alter he would learn that morse had actually requested him and that strange, utterly relieved that he would finally ask for someone by name, had immediately handed Robbie over like a parcel even though he would never have said it like that in front of either of them.
And so, here they were, with another case under their belt, doing the paperwork in Morse’s office, or perhaps, rather, Robbie doing most of it while Morse was busy listening to some classics LP or another, but that too, he had known before..
If he had ever imagined something like that, he would perhaps have thought that Morse would just go and not keep him company, so he supposed that was something, and he knew through the grapevine that hr controlled every piece of paperwork that passed his desk anyway even if he didn’t want anyone to know.
When eh was done, he stood up and handed Morse the files, feeling ever so slightly down. He actually enjoyed working with him, much as yes, he could be a difficult, miserable sod, but that was neither here nor there anyway…
"That was good work" Morse then sad as if it was nothing.
It actually rendered him speechless for a second – had Morse just – he really had to mark this date in his calendar. This was undoubtedly the pinnacle of his career, unless he actually managed to do the bloody course and become an inspector, as Val aways said he would, but Robbie always figured she was a bit biased when it came to him and what he was capable of.
“I – I – “ he cleared his throat. “Thank you, sir.”
Morse looked at him and nodded, once, twice, seemingly thinking about something, then saying, “You’re without a governor at the moment, aren’t you?”
He shrugged. “There are only so many inspectors who need a bagman, and currently they all have one.” He always told himself not to be too disappointed when yet another one of his colleagues was picked. True, he usually prided himself on getting along with pretty much everyone, so why he of all people should not yet have been asked to be someone’s bagman, but anyway, that was neither here nor there, and –
“I could use someone. If you want to work with me, that is.”
He needed a moment or two to understand what Morse was saying, just because he would never have thought it possible. Yes, he had enjoyed working with him on that aces, notwithstanding the fact that a woman had lost her life, but still, this was DCI Morse, and he would never –
“Of course it’s not mandatory. There is no –“
“Yes, sir I would like that very much” he interrupted him before he could let that chance pass him by even though he still hadn’t quite grasped what was happening.
“Alright then”. He raised an eyebrow. “Time for a drink at the pub, le-wis.”
And even though it was just the beginning of him leaving way too large of a portion of his wages at public houses, he would never regret it.
writing_prompt: A seasoned sergeant with a knack for getting along with everyone is unexpectedly asked to partner with a brilliant but notoriously difficult detective inspector. How do you navigate a partnership with someone who solves cases effortlessly but challenges your patience at every turn?

title: I Saw Your Eyes Light Up
post_title: He cannot begin to express what a feeling it is to be back in London again. There is finally proper tea around every corner, as opposed to just one place on an entire island that serves it (not that he would ever say so out loud on saint Marie, catherine must never know), it rains (real rain, cold, wet, terrible rain) and he can walk down the streets without being assaulted by colours everywhere (although eh will admit that he doesn’t mind the colours too much, all things considered. They are… well, they liven up a place, he is ready to admit that if only to himself).
comment:
He cannot begin to express what a feeling it is to be back in London again. There is finally proper tea around every corner, as opposed to just one place on an entire island that serves it (not that he would ever say so out loud on saint Marie, catherine must never know), it rains (real rain, cold, wet, terrible rain) and he can walk down the streets without being assaulted by colours everywhere (although eh will admit that he doesn’t mind the colours too much, all things considered. They are… well, they liven up a place, he is ready to admit that if only to himself).
Although at the same time… something is missing, and he just can’t put his finger on it, which frustrates him because it’s basically his job to do just that.
He’ll figure it out eventually, he tells himself, because he always does. He doesn’t mention it to anyone, of course, because it is ridiculous.
Plus, it’s not like anyone could actually help him in this regard (or so he thinks). After all, he doesn’t really have friends (if he doesn’t count Camille and his team on Saint Marie) and when it comes to his parents.. well… they are not.. that close (like Camille and Catherine, for example). And he’s not in the habit of making small talk anyway (although dad called him a chatterbox not long ago because he was describing the market on the island and got carried away).
But really, if he were to review his stay in London so far, eh would say that all has been going rather well. The lats few days especially, when he was wrapping everything up and working through when he can return to Saint maire, which will be in five days time, not that he is counting.
And then Mum jumps on him the second he enters their house, telling him she’s made tea, and at first he doesn’t understand why she seems so eager, and then –
“So you say Saint Marie is lovely at this time of the year?”
“Hot. As always”.
She tuts. “I bet your colleagues don’t mind it.”
“They grew up there” he explains. “They’re used to it. And Camille specially –“ And then he’s off explaining again that she is after him to install an A/C, but that it would be a waste in his shack.
After he falls silent, Mum seems to think about something or other, so he searches fort a topic of conversation and has started asking after old Mrs. Webster from next door, when –
“I saw your eyes light up” his mother then declares in one of those non-sequiturs she loves, and Richar is once again lost.
“I beg your pardon?”
She shakes her head. “When you mentioned Camille. I saw your eyes light up.”
“I – what does that even mean?” Eyes do not light up. He is aware it’s used metaphorically, of course, but even so, he could never quite understand what people meant by it.
She gives him a look he remembers from his teen years when he dared try and smoke cigarettes in his room – alright, one cigarette, one afternoon, and that expression put a stop to it immediately. But he’s no longer a child, so –
“Tell me more about Camille” she then demands, and he can’t really say anything against that because she is his second in command, and he likes to imagine a friend, even if he would dispute the fact as he did already once before when she seemed to suggest such.
Ade so, he talks about Camille and how she made him agree to small talk in the mornings and spending time at la Kaz after the day is done and that she likes to show up and drag him out of his “monastic cell” as she insists on calling it and that he usually goes with her because it’s easier… undoubtedly Mum, who has always appreciated her own company too, otherwise she would hardly have married his father, who can be even more silent than Richard on any given occasion, will understand that it can be frustrating for him –
But for some reason, she just keeps smiling, and he keeps talking and…
He forces himself to stop because certainly no one should know this much about a colleague, but Mum simply smiles again and pats his hand. “I’m sure your differences are not all that great, dearest. It will all work out.”
He’s not quite sure what she means, but instead focuses back on what he has to pack.
Mum will tell him, she usually does.
As she indeed does, five years later when she convinces Dad to move to Saint Marie once and for all so they can watch their grandchildren grow up, Camille more than happy to help her parents-in-law settle in.
writing_prompt: Back in London, surrounded by familiar rain and proper tea, he can't shake the feeling that something—or someone—is missing. When his mother casually mentions how his eyes light up at the mention of Camille, he begins to wonder if the island he left behind holds more than just sunshine and work.

title: I'm Not Okay
post_title: The thing was, Peter had known from the beginning that this was a really really terrible idea. Much as the Chairman would protest that the Captain should be able to handle all of this because he hadn’t seen his family in years, because it was his duty, because he should know better – the Chairman wasn’t human, it was as plain and simple as that. They didn’t talk about that, of course, because it would not be very wise, but still. The point was, he could not, would not get that Dev was suffering just by being in the town he had grown up in, knowing his family lived and breathed and laughed within its walls and had no idea that there was someone missing from their midst.
comment:
The thing was, Peter had known from the beginning that this was a really really terrible idea. Much as the Chairman would protest that the Captain should be able to handle all of this because he hadn’t seen his family in years, because it was his duty, because he should know better – the Chairman wasn’t human, it was as plain and simple as that. They didn’t talk about that, of course, because it would not be very wise, but still. The point was, he could not, would not get that Dev was suffering just by being in the town he had grown up in, knowing his family lived and breathed and laughed within its walls and had no idea that there was someone missing from their midst.
But with all of that… there was something else, and that was that Peter was reasonably sure he was the only one who knew how bad it was. Partly because he and Dev were not accustomed to hide things from one another, and partly because… well… mow that he was building up the Guard, no one would dare to question how he was doing and what he was feeling.
No one except Peter that was, but they were friends – as a matter of fact, Dev was the first friend he had ever made in his life.
And so, he kept a close eye on Dev, even closer than usual, that was – with magic involved, it was always a good idea to Saty on one’s guard, in case anyone tried anything, so he was already careful. It was one of the things he’d had to accept when he had chosen this life, but he did not regret it and very much suspected that he never would.
Now, when it came to them, they were used to what they called their bad nights. When Peter remembered the cane or dev woke up from a dream believing to be sixteen years old again with Joan and Sam clamoring for his attention, when a case reminded them that time was fleeting and that any day they might – they had experience dealing with such things, that was what he meant to say, but all of this – is what usually just that – a bad night. Not a constant deluge of being reminded what they could not have, and it was easy to tell that it was wearing Dev down, only that he would not admit I because he would not risk being sent back to London, so there was no way that he could just… ask. Because there were lines he did not cross, not when it came to Dev’s family.
Or maybe not because he woke up and could just tell it was a Abd night. They usually could, although peter knew that he himself had had much more bad nights than Dev over the years, although his friend would deny that.
He got up and went into the living room and found Dev standing at the window, staring out at the city he had tried so hard to get back to, only that it was not the city he had left behind on that fateful day.
“Hey” he said as usual, sitting down because asking would lead to nothing. He knew him too well for that.
It took a while but eventually Dev walked over and sat down too, staring at his folded hands.
Perter continued to wait.
“No“ he finally said, even though Peter had as of yet asked no questions, quietly like a confession, like something shameful even though it was not, it very much was not, “I’m not okay”.
An understatement of course, the bloody understatement of the bloody century, but there was nothing they could o about it. Even if Dev could have left Oxford again – which he would have refused to do anyway – it would not have done any good, now that he had seen them, now that they were playing happy family in front of him – no, not playing, just
being
a happy family, and that made everything worse, so much worse –
Peter did not know what to say. How could he even begin to understand? Dev himself was the closest thing he had ever had to a family, and he wasn’t quite sure being taken in after almost having been devoured by a vampire counted.
He stared down into his tea, wishing it could be something stronger but at the same time aware that this was a slippery slope, a very slippery slope indeed, and that he might not stop if he ever started.
“I – “ he finally began because despite the many, many nights they had spent like this, he still didn’t know what to say.
Dev glanced at him then, smiled and said, “Thank you, Peter.”
And for some reason, it was enough yet again.
writing_prompt: When your closest friend returns to the city he once called home, the weight of his past begins to unravel him—and you’re the only one who sees just how deep the cracks run.

title: Let me Remind You
post_title: He’d been working, if he wanted to call this working and not indentured servitude, which, if you asked Neal, was still debatable, at the FBI for about a year and a half now, as Mozzie got never tired of reminding him. Not that it changed much – he was simply sitting out his sentence, but thankfully not in a cell, and he couldn’t deny that he did good, occasionally, which might not have done much for his reputation but nonetheless left him feeling somewhat accomplished at the end of the day.
comment:
He’d been working, if he wanted to call this working and not indentured servitude, which, if you asked Neal, was still debatable, at the FBI for about a year and a half now, as Mozzie got never tired of reminding him. Not that it changed much – he was simply sitting out his sentence, but thankfully not in a cell, and he couldn’t deny that he did good, occasionally, which might not have done much for his reputation but nonetheless left him feeling somewhat accomplished at the end of the day.
And really, all in all, it wasn’t too bad. He might not have been his own master, but he planned to rectify that soon, and anyway, for now, it was even sort of fun to have a 9 to 5 job most of the time since he had never really known what that was.
And he couldn’t deny that he enjoyed spending time with Peter – as a matter of fact, one of the reasons he had already more than once drawn back from making definitive plans was that he would never see him, Elizabeth or the other people he had slowly come to call his friends once he was done here.
But well, while he was still here, he might as well take this seriously because it got Peter off his back and made people think he was resigned to this, so he might as well just have some fun… by taking it seriously (it did not have to makes sense to other people, as he would have told Mozzie).
And so, when a new case rolled around and he shared the team’s frustration at not being able to lay hand on the suspect and another agent just strolled in acting like he was the next big thing, Neal just… snapped.
Agent Linder had been going on and on abet this case, how he was the one who first realized something was off about the bank statements, how he deserved to bring in the culprit, how it would bring him forward and he would finally get some much-deserved recognition (it was clear what he was angling for, but good luck with that, Neal knew they were still waiting for Peter to want Organized Crime).
What he meant to say was, he just couldn’t take it anymore, and so, when the man finally needed to take a deep breath…
“Let me remind you“ Neal said impatiently. “We need a warrant to be able to search the place, or rather, to ensure that everything we find can be used in court, bevues if it can’t, we might as well do nothing at all.”
Linder shot him a dirty look, but he couldn’t have cared less. If they wanted to get this guy off the streets, then they had –
It was then that he realized what he had just said, and what he had been thinking, and he quickly went to get coffee.
He shook his head at himself as he poured himself a cup. That case last week where he had yet again pretended that he was an FBI agent must be catching up with him. Thank God Mozzie had not been around, he would never have heard the end of it.
He had hoped that his outburst had gone unnoticed, but that had perhaps been too much to ask, especially with Peter Burke around. Art first, he didn’t think much of it when his friend joined him – Peter was worse than him when it came to coffee, as June’s depleted Italian roast stash could attest – but then he causally said, “You were right, of course.”
“Yes” he agreed automatically then asked just to make sure “About what?”
“With Linder just now. We can’t do anything without a warrant, and with the evidence we have now, or lack thereof, no judge would sign one.”
“Just wanted to save some time. He is rather insufferable.”
“You can say that again” Peter told him, uncharacteristically grinning (well the grinning in itself was not uncharacteristic, but that he should do so while complaining about a  colleague certainly was). “I am just glad you reminded him of the correct procedure.”
“I wouldn’t go so far.”
Peter shrugged even though it was clear he did not agree.
“Whatever, don’t get used to it. I just wanted to take him down a peg or two.”
“Of course, of course, never” Peter agreed. “Nothing else going on here.”
“And don’t you forget it.”
“I won’t.”
He really, really did not, for even years later, after all was said and done and he’d finally admitted some truths to himself and done what ought to be done after his sentence was complete, his friend Peter Burke still laughed every time Special Agent Neal Caffrey reprimanded a young colleague for risking a case by not following the correct procedure.
writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.

title: I'm Not Giving Up
post_title: In the beginning, Camille would be the first to admit, she had hated working with Richard.
comment:
In the beginning, Camille would be the first to admit, she had hated working with Richard. He had seemed pedantic, rude and unlikeable, and in some ways, she would admit that he was… just… not the way she had thought. Yes, he did not quite understand social cues now and then, and he could be stubborn when running down a lead, but she had come to realize he also cared deeply about the victims and that each and every case should be wrapped up because it was his duty to do so.
And this was just another example.
Alice Morgan had been found dead a week ago on the beach, and there was almost nothing to go on. The tide had gotten to her before she had been found – really it was a miracle that she had not been swept away by the sea, which was undoubtedly what the murderer had wanted – there was little evidence, no reason why someone should murder her, nothing.
Camille had seen enough such cases over the course of her career to feel that it was hopeless, and was all but resigned to that fact.
Richard, as it turned out, not so much.
They had all gone home for the day. There was nothing to be done until they got the lab results back, although Camille was rather sure that that would lead to nothing, either, so she did it best not to think about it –
Until she’d realized she’d forgotten her wallet at the station because she’d had to reorganise her purse and her drawers (maman, when she told her alter, would make some comments about imitating a certain someone, but there would be enough interesting developments for her to deal with anyway) and quickly returned to grab it. And what she found was Richard still going through the evidence.
She glanced at her watch – close to ten pm. She had known he worked long hours, of course, just like she was aware that he found it difficult to sleep anyway with the weather (and she was trying, really trying, to get him to find a place with a proper AC, figuring he would not be so cranky if eh wasn’t so hot all the time).
Wondering if she should say something, then deciding that against all odds, they were friends, she cleared her throat as she stepped into the station. “Ricard, I didn’t know you were still here…”
He looked up and blinked, clearly needing a moment or two to recognize her, and she would have Eben worried if she ah dot come to understand him much better than she had at the beginning. He had simply been lost in thought and she just had to wait.
Then he asked, “Camille? Is there something you need?” as if he was not working late into the night.
“I just needed something from my desk, that is all…” after a moment or two she added “§I didn’t think anyone would still be here.”
“I told you before, in London we usually have two teams, so really, this is just me trying my best…”
And naturally he had not mentioned it to anyone because why would he. She suppressed a sigh than sat down at her desk. “Fine, let’s go over it again.”
“I – oh –“ he was clearly surprised “Camille, you don’t have to – I am sure you have plans – “
“As a matter of fact I don’t, and even if I had, why should you work away all alone?”
It was then that he shrugged and said quietly “I’m used to it.”
“Richard” she tried, “We really have to make sure we’re well-“
“I’m not giving up” he interrupted her stubbornly. The victim serves justice, and –“
And she realized that this was not about Richard being right, or proving himself better than the rest of the team, or anything else she would have assumed just after he had been transferred here.
No, this was simply about solving the case, giving the victim back whatever dignity they could have, and she raised a hand to quietly say, “Richard, I know.”
This interrupted him mid-rant and he looked at her, then nodded, as if he was shocked that she had agreed.
Then a groan made itself known and she raised an eyebrow. “You didn’t have dinner, did you?”
“I – “ he cleared his throat. “I figured this was more important –“
“It is important, but you need to keep up your strength.” She made a quick decision. “Come on, I can make you something quick at my place.”
He blushed. “Camille, I – just – It’s very kind of you, but – “
“No buts. Come on.” And against all odds, he followed her.
At least in later years, she didn’t have to tell him to come to dinner. Sending one of their children to fetch Dad usually did the trick.
writing_prompt: Two detectives, once at odds but now an unlikely team, find themselves working late on a seemingly unsolvable case. As the night deepens, they uncover not just new leads, but a deeper understanding of each other.

title: We've Done Worse
post_title: The last thing he expected was that Peter’s – well, he doesn’t even know what to call it. Re-education seems a little harsh, considering the historical connotations, and everything else is just… wrong. Rehabilitation? He doesn’t think he ever really was one of those who needed that. Yes, he forged art and lied and stole, but that’s hardly worth a place in hell. Restitution? Not the proper word to use, and anyway, it’s not like he’s giving back any of what he stole. The FBI already seized most of it, and what little there remains is not exactly the most expensive of the bunch.
comment:
The last thing he expected was that Peter’s – well, he doesn’t even know what to call it. Re-education seems a little harsh, considering the historical connotations, and everything else is just… wrong. Rehabilitation? He doesn’t think he ever really was one of those who needed that. Yes, he forged art and lied and stole, but that’s hardly worth a place in hell. Restitution? Not the proper word to use, and anyway, it’s not like he’s giving back any of what he stole. The FBI already seized most of it, and what little there remains is not exactly the most expensive of the bunch.
The point is, he really didn’t think he’s changing in any way, shape or form. He might have a nine-to-five, but he hates it (or so eh thought). It’s nice to have dinner with Peter and Elizabeth sometimes but it doesn’t take away the fact that he can only walk so far without being arrested (he was convinced). It’s one thing to be able to solve cases and help people, but another when one is forced to do so (he believed).
So, really, he was just a crook who flew too close to the sun, as Mozzie put it, got caught, then got lucky and that is why he is not in jail and biding his time. Easy, right?
As it turns out, not so much.
He’s been going through some files. Nothing big, nothing that needs their immediate attention, but if he doesn’t, there’ll be repercussions, mainly that Peter will have to do it on his own, he’ll be late for dinner, and Elizabeth will be annoyed, not to mention that Diana and Jones will roll their eyes, and anyway, it’s easy enough work for a few hours. Mozzie sends him a text that they need to talk, but that can mean anything and is not alarming really so he decides to ignore it until he gets home that night.
Mozzie is waiting for him, having opened a bottle of wine, of course.
“What is it?” he asks when her realizes his friend his unnaturally excited, even for his standards.
As it turns out, it’s a von Alt. Not extremely well known over here, but fetching a lot in Europe, so – perfect. Also, currently being house in one of the smaller museums in Manhattan, being on permanent loan from a millionaire how seems to consider it his duty to let other people enjoy works of art too instead of letting them rot in some vault or another which, from what he knows of that kind of people, is positively philanthropic. Also a bit stupid, but it just gives them the chance to… to…
He says no without even thinking about it. There’s just something that rubs him the wrong way. Also, it’s next week, and there’s an audit coming up, not to mention Diana and Jones will be in court, and Peter is –
“We’ve done worse” Mozzie say and he automatically opens his mouth to argue only to realize that in fact, they have, They have, as mentioned before, stolen and lied and cheated, and he has never even batted an eye, because it’s unfair that some people have nice things and they don’t. It’s just how life works – sometimes you have to help justice along if you actually want to see it done…
But this… well… this is not one of those times. This is literally just them being annoyed that another rich guy has a painting. If he were hiding it away, that would be one thing, but it’s literally on loan to the gallery, and so people get to see it. Everyone is happy with that, apart from people who want it for themselves or need the money, and…
Well… Neal does get paid. Not a lot. But there
is
compensation. And anyway, if something happened and Peter realized what was going on – always a risk, although until now, it just added to the gun of it – he’d hunt them down again because this is Peter they are speaking of.
“I know” he finally answers because he realizes Mozzie expects him to. ”It’s just – “ and then he realizes he has no idea what to say to even start to explain what’s going on in his head, because it seems that part of him is a law-abiding citizen all of a sudden and it’s a little bit too much for him to comprehend.
“Look I’m not saying never, alright? I’m just saying some other time” he tries to save himself, only for Mozzie to raise an eyebrow.
“Fine, fine, mon frère, just don’t expect me to join you on your new side any time soon.”
There’s no new side, he thinks, shaking his Hea. He’s just being careful and deliberately choosing what to do, that’s all.
If only he could believe himself.
writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?

title: I know you better
post_title:
At first, he cannot believe it.
This is, this is finally it.
He could be his own man again, could be free again in a week.
comment:
At first, he cannot believe it.
This is, this is finally it.
Right there, in the file he has been working on through sheer boredom, is a list of accounts on the Kaiman islands, hidden in plain view. He doubts anyone who has not done a little shuffling and coding themselves would be able to figure it out.
Which is why Peter gave him the file, of course. He’s supposed to tell him immediately, and then they can shut this down, get the money back to those it belongs to.
But
, a voice in Neal’s head whispers,
does it really matter
? It’s gone, and there is every reason to suppose the victims were insured for that kind of thing. He most likely could grab the cash for himself and no one would be the wiser, only that he would have everything eh could need to – need to –
He quickly outs a plan together. He could be out of here by the middle of next week.
And then Peter steps out of his office, does the two-finger-point, and he automatically gets up to see him.
“And?” Peter asks because of course at the moment he can only mean that one case. That many millions going missing tend to make the higher-ups nervous.
“He’s certainly creative” Neal says, playfully opening and closing the file because this is what peter expects from him and the last thing he needs is to arouse suspicion. “Thinks outside the box, has a tendency to –“
“Yes, yes, but I definitely don’t need a detailed critique of his work. I need to know what he did with the money.”
And this is when he makes his mistake, although not in the way he would have supposed he would, if he’d thought about it at all. “How do you know” he says “that I haven’t figured it out already? Might make a run for it.”
Peter chuckles – as if it’s a joke when this is Neal Caffrey they are talking about, the man an entire Bureau of agents couldn’t catch until Peter Burke figured out his one weakness, and he almost feels a little angry.
Until the next words escape Peter’s mouth.
“I know you better“ he says, when he really doesn’t. When, as a matter of fact, he should be aware that Neal hasn’t really changed, did not take any of the lessons he was supposed to learn to heart, was only ever trying to get away.
Neal looks at him, in his hands his ticket out of here, to another life, one without a nine-to-five job, where he gets to do what he wants again, perhaps live in Paris or Rome or Florence, where he has no responsibilities, no watch dogs, no ties holding him down –
And he realizes that Peter knows, but that he cannot stop him. What he needs is there in the file, and he has a right to read it because he is his CI, and what he does in his spare time…
He looks into his eyes and those words, those four words, keep repeating themselves in his head.
I know you better. I know you better. I know you better.
Really what does it matter that he is about to prove Peter wrong? He has disappointed him often enough. And leaving, that’s all he’s ever wanted since he took this deal, isn’t it? It got him out of prison, but this was never supposed to last. It was just his ticket out of his cell so he could go look for Kate, and then of course that – that –
And after, what else was he supposed to do? If he hadn’t stuck around, the FBI would have been after him faster than he could blink, so he had to wait just a few more months, and then there was so much to do, or a case that he couldn’t leave just to Peter because it would have meant him all but camping in his office again, and then he would have been in El’s black books…
More time has passed than Neal wants to admit himself, although he wants to dwell on the reason, the real reason for that even less.
I know you better.
He looks into Peter’s eyes and makes the decision without being aware of it, without thinking,
yes, let’s do this.
Instead, he just answers, “let me take another look.” And he opens the file.
No all is lost yet. He might – “That’s a code. Let me see what I can do about it.”
And he knows he’s done it now because even if he pretended not to figure it out, Peter would realize there was something.
And yet there is no regret, no anger at himself, nothing.
Peter nods at him, smiling. “Alright. Let me know.”
And he nods back and returns to – his desk.
writing_prompt: Faced with the ultimate temptation—a file containing the key to millions in stolen money—Neal Caffrey must decide between the freedom he’s always craved and the trust of the one person who believes he’s changed. What does he choose, and why?

title: It's A New Day Let's Go
post_title: When it came to humans, Crowley had learned that early on, there was always something.
comment:
When it came to humans, Crowley had learned that early on, there was always something. One could never trust that they were done, even if they had managed to gather in a group and build a city and procured everything they needed to live comfortably; no, there was always something more, and that something more usually consisted on them fighting over nothing, or at least nothing that made sense. It was one of those things that made them so frustrating and so interesting at the same time.
At elates, even he would admit that, this Solomon fellow was rather clever. Being a judge, settling disputes left and right. New, technically he should have been against all of that, being a demon and so on, but at the same time… you had to admire him, just a little-. Most humans, no, most demons, he – heaven. Most angels would not have done such a good job, which he was very aware of because he had once worked closely with Gabriel and it had not been a pleasant experience.
Quite different from that very first time he had met –
“Angel” he greeted him, strolling up to Aziraphale, who was watching the proceedings utterly enchanted, as he was wont to when humans proved how clever they could be.
He turned to him. “He – oh. Crowley.”
At times like these, he wondered if Aziraphale remembered when they had first met, when they had still been angels, but it didn’t matter. All that was long gone now, simply because he had dared asked questions, and now they were hereditary enemies, or at least supposed to be, although that had never stopped them from getting on since Eden, even though from his perspective, Aziraphale would have had every reason to get angry at him.
“Pretty clever that Solomon, you have to admit” he said. “Seeing which woman would be ready to give the child up rather than watch them being cut in half.”
“Yes” Aziraphale replied, looking at him and frowning. It’s – I mean – only – a little bit ruthless for someone who is supposed to be so God-fearing…”
“But effective. Humans will talk about this for millennia to come.” He could already see a man scribbling away on one of those clay tablets that were all the range, these days. Undoubtedly this was one of those scenes that would get passed down, although it would probably get a bit distorted across the years because that was how things tended to work out when they got involved.
Crowley personally found it rather interesting, but he knew some of the other demons were more angry than anything else – probably supposed to be because that was what they were, and the angels –
Better not go there. Apart from – his angel, he had never really gotten along with any of them, even back when he was still an angel himself.
Not that he had fared any better with the other demons. He was starting to think that Aziraphale was just an exception – as wonderful and as strange as it was disconcerting, and yet he would not have traded their… relationship (not a relationship, of course not, not like that, nit like the humans, why was he even thinking about that, it was utterly ridiculous, it could not be, it would not be, and he was going to stop thinking about this right now).
“I do hope the child will have a good life” Aziraphale said, wringing his hands, and Crowley did not know what to say. Human lives could be very fickle and complicated, so…
“She would not have done this just to let them fall later” he said vine though he was far from certain about this. So, instead, he decided to nudge him and move on. Only that he was surprised at the words that escaped his mouth.
"it's a new day, let's go". He had no idea why he would say something like that, and whether it would work – first of all, there were not really days in Heaven or Hell, so they were not used to this sort of talk and second of all, why should Aziraphale go with him? It was asinine to –
“There is a nice little tavern three streets over.”
He blinked then looked at the angel, then towards where he was pointing, ridiculous of course because not even they with their powers could see that far without performing a miracle, and while he could easily have done so, doing it in front of Aziraphale would mean that his – friend? Were they fiends? He thought so, but he had no idea if Aziraphale felt the same way, but this was only in his thoughts, so his friend – yes he would be asked to explain the miracle, so he didn’t think about and indeed turned back to him.
“Alright then” he agreed and off they were.
writing_prompt: After witnessing Solomon's famous judgment, Crowley and Aziraphale find themselves debating the cleverness and morality of human ingenuity—until Crowley suggests a nearby tavern, and the two unlikely companions set off, their centuries-old bond as complicated as ever.
